text:
Honestly, I think it's terrible to have a workwide pileon demanding some guy gets fired because he has some idiotic beliefs that has nothing to do with his job. It has an appalling mix of mob justice, self-righteousness, totalitarianism and 10,000-against-one pileon.
Let people believe things - even insane things - right up until they try to encode those actions into policy or law.

Let people believe things - even insane things - right up until they try to encode those actions into policy or law.

text: Then don't sign it ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I don't exactly follow it closely, so stallman may well have done things for which I'd consider this sort of protest appropriate, however, I have certainly seen some complaints against him that have struck me as absurd and, more importantly, to <@U7HAYKY9X>’s excellent point, he doesn't have to be not-a-jackass to work with him.  Plenty of people are total assholes and also do a lot of great work.  Trying to "purge" everyone you think is a difficult personality is not only a terrible idea in practice, but in many cases reveals many of the undesirable personality traits the purgee is accused of having in the purger

text: "Undesirable personality" here is erasing his decades of sexual harassment. This is not just about beliefs, but patterns of abusive behavior spanning multiple decades, institutions and conferences that coddled his skirting basic behavior rules *specifically written to stop him* from doing so and looking the other way.

text:
I am sure the stewards (I presume) that made the rule perfectly well understood the implications of not allowing politics on the Julia slack (both the good and the bad). Personally, I would think allowing politics would be perfectly fine but I also believe that one should keep to the rules (or CoC if you wish) of the community one is a part of so while the rule is in place, I think it should be kept.

But there is a very worthwhile discussion to be have about forbidding politics keeps the status quo and perhaps that rule should be removed.

text: I think this particular case is less about politics than about rms being an all-around terrible person and hard to work with. The only direct thing I know about him were his posts on the emacs mailing list, and almost without exception they were unhelpful, abrasive, ideological to the point of nonsense, and mostly ignored by the people actually doing work. The guy was a major positive influence on the world but he should just have retired a few decades ago

text:
I'm sorry, but as <@U677NAWV8> wrote, for some of us our very _existence_ is considered a political statement, although through no fault of our own. I, for instance, am a gay, autistic man. Now is this relevant to most discussions on this Slack channel? No, it's not. But it's still part of my identity, something I carry with me at all times, even in this Slack channel. So when I see people on here defend absolutely horrible people because they are "entitled to their opinions" and that efforts to call them out on their toxic opinions _and behaviours_ are branded as "far-leftist authoritarian dogwhistles", I start wondering whether I'm actually welcome in this community. Is my existence really respected at all, or just tolerated as long as people think I'm just another straight neurotypical guy?
_This_ is what happens when you defend other people's right to their "opinions", you're making other people who _are_ here, who _are_ reading your comments, feel less welcome and safe. Is that so political to ask simply to be treated as equals worthy of respect for who we are? And you shouldn't _have_ to be part of the minority being attacked to be able to speak out against prejudice. There's such a thing as empathy.
Finally, one last thing to consider: an opinion is whether pineapple on pizza is acceptable or not, not whether a certain group of people are allowed to exist.

text:
>  Is that so political to ask simply to be treated as equals worthy of respect for who we are? 
Absolutely not, that is in the Julia CoC (<https://julialang.org/community/standards/>) and if you see people do otherwise you should report them to the stewards.

elements.text: Is that so political to ask simply to be treated as equals worthy of respect for who we are?

) and if you see people do otherwise you should report them to the stewards.

text: However, your reaction mirrors very much about what happened that caused the politics ban in the first place (at least from my memory). People claimed that being a Trump supporter / Republican was against the Julia CoC, some people "defended" the Republicans, people said that was offensive and all of a sudden there was a lot of heated discussion taking place. The decision was made to not allow politics based on (from what I assume) pragmatism.

The decision was made to not allow politics based on (from what I assume) pragmatism.

text:
My reaction is how I _feel_. I'm not _offended_, I feel _unsafe_ and _unwelcome_. That's not politics nor "heated discussion". That's me getting metaphorically hit in the face and then hearing I should not speak out because the punch wasn't directed at me, I just happened to be in the way. It's all fine to put up a politics ban, but that doesn't help those of us whose very existence has been deemed political by others.
I'm not saying the politics ban should go. I'm in another community with a "no cross no crown" policy and it's one of the best places I've been and I've been there for the last 25 years. But you can still have such a ban and allow people to speak out against prejudice, even if they're not personally victim of it.
Finally, if you are serious about diversity, then you have no choice but calling some opinions out. Diversity, after all, is not "all opinions welcome". It's "all _people_ welcome". Opinions that inherently or effectively exclude some groups for something that is inherent to their existence, simply have no place in a diverse environment.

text:
> for some of us our very _existence_ is considered a political statement
Considered by whom? The general society? Sure. But we are trying to be better here, aren’t we? I don’t consider your existence a political statement and in particular not in this community!

> their very existence in a community is inherently a political statement, and not everyone has the privilege of living in an apolitical environment
While I generally agree with you guys, isn’t the purpose of the “no-politics” rule precisely an attempt to make the Julia community such an apolitical environment (where everyone can feel safe and welcome)?

Anyways, I think we as a community need to make a decision. Do we want to be apolitical and non-opinionated or do we want to stand in for things (which, I think, in many cases that the vast majority of us agree on - at least I like to think that :D).

text:
> I'm not offended, I feel unsafe and unwelcome. 
I think that prevention of those feelings is exactly the reason the political ban was instated in the first place, based on experiences from previous similar topics. A discussion quite similar to this one took place (except for RMS it was Trump/Republicans), the same type of comments happened, people got hurt and in the end it was decided that these type of discussions on this slack was not appropriate. So far, I think it has worked quite well and looking at the results of this thread, and your stated feelings, it probably would have been better with some moderator action here earlier (although from my understanding, Slack basically has no moderator tools because it isn't aimed for communities).

text:
But what does how you feel actually imply <@UPSSPPBFV>? As I understand it, when you say
> So when I see people on here defend absolutely horrible people because 
> they are "entitled to their opinions" and that efforts to call them out 
> on their toxic opinions _and behaviours_ are branded as "far-leftist authoritarian dogwhistles", I start wondering whether I'm actually welcome in this community.
Perhaps I'm misunderstanding, and if so, do correct me. But the implication of what you say that is that the community implicitly must choose: Either we allow people like me to voice opinions like I did above  - importantly *not even defending Stallman*, but just going against this mob-justice and leftwing authoritarianism, and _absoutely not_ questioning whether everyone should be welcome here - OR else people like you can't/won't be here. And I'm pretty sure you think the community should choose the latter.
That's a very, very dangerous path to take. It means that people voicing opinions that _in no way conflicts with Julias CoC_, or harasses anyone, etc, should be purged because their ideology does not conform.

text:
<@U67D54KS8> I agree this thread probably leads nowhere good. But one problem with the "no politics" rule is that part of what we're arguing about is whether this is even politics. There is this human tendency to believe, if your beliefs are not ever questioned or you meet people with different beliefs, that your beliefs are simply common sense, not politics.
The thing I'm worried about is that this community decides on a "no-politics" rule, and then implicitly decides that only things like what *I* said in this thread politics, and the leftwing consensus is apolitical common sense.

text:
What I wish was more often part of this conversation is a recognition that people's needs can be in conflict. I believe there could be a world where RMS was in a community (e.g. MIT) that supported him more adequately instead of letting problems fester until a dam ruptures. In that world, there would be less harm done unto people.

I bring this up because I think there's a lesson for any community to have robust communication, offer support, and practice some amount of rehabilitation when someone has harmed and/or been harmed. And I hope that the Julia community always aspires to some utopia where we all get along. The truth is that we unintentionally harm one another regularly, in ways we cannot even know. I believe a CoC can help to a considerable extent, but it cannot "codify away" the conversation that's happening in this thread without disrupting the mechanisms I mean in the beginning of this paragraph.

And to be clear, I do not mean "rehabilitate at all costs". How to figure out what's worth what, and how much damage has been done is imo squarely within a looser definition of "politics".

And I hope that the Julia community always aspires to some utopia where we all get along. The truth is that we unintentionally harm one another regularly, in ways we cannot even know. text:
Thank you <@UPSSPPBFV> for speaking out. I'm going to use my privilege as an old-timer and Problematic Developer to echo this: the need to distinguish between diversity and inclusion of people _over opinions_ is critical (c.f. the paradox of tolerance). It's a very privileged position to be comfortable enough to causally dismiss the struggles of others. Statements that openly question the validity of people's lived experiences have no place in our community, or any that is serious about diversity and inclusion. 30% of trans youth have attempted to commit suicide and 2/3 of trans adults feel that it is unsafe to come out at their workplace. Similar statistics exist for disabled people. Anyone at my workplace who openly mocks transphobia and ableism would find themselves in front of HR very quickly.

To circle back to the original post, RMS has a long history of problematic opinions and behavior, who has openly stated that foetuses with Down's syndrome should be aborted with no moral ambiguity. He has sexually harassed many women at MIT which has led to his expulsion from CSAIL. These are the kinds of behaviors that IMO don't deserve any tolerance, especially given the persistent and recalcitrant history of not making any attempt to improve. Reinstating a person like this to a position of power goes against DEI efforts to make communities more welcoming.

Statements that openly question the validity of people's lived experiences have no place in our community, or any that is serious about diversity and inclusion. 30% of trans youth have attempted to commit suicide and 2/3 of trans adults feel that it is unsafe to come out at their workplace. Similar statistics exist for disabled people. Anyone at my workplace who openly mocks transphobia and ableism would find themselves in front of HR very quickly.

To circle back to the original post, RMS has a long history of problematic opinions and behavior, who has openly stated that foetuses with Down's syndrome should be aborted with no moral ambiguity. He has sexually harassed many women at MIT which has led to his expulsion from CSAIL. These are the kinds of behaviors that IMO don't deserve any tolerance, especially given the persistent and recalcitrant history of not making any attempt to improve. Reinstating a person like this to a position of power goes against DEI efforts to make communities more welcoming.

text:
Thanks for sharing everyone, I find it all quite educating. Personally I find that the more I read about these subjects the more confused I am. I cant say I often feel like one side of an argument has the truth in their hands, but who am I to know this. What I do think to know is that trying to make people feel welcome is clearly a good thing.

I'd like to think - and maybe thats a bit naive - that the perception of increased conflict in untypical places is a good sign for progress. As an analogy: I read once that when a country starts fighting its corruption issues, that it first appears to become more corrupt because of the increase of scrutiny and media attention.

text:
>  I, for instance, am a gay, autistic man.
Thanks so much for being open about that.
I am trying to get my 18 year old son to learn Julia (he will be starting university in the fall, in CS).
I hope he finds more role models such as you if he joins this Slack (he is also on the spectrum, and came out two years ago), and not opinions that make would make him feel unwanted here, such as:
> all the far-leftist authoritarian dogwhistles of “transphobia”, “ableist” et cetera.

text: Thanks <@UB7JS9CHF>, your comment is exactly the reason why I am so open and vocal about such issues, in every community where I am active. I don't care how much pushback I get, because it's somehow "political" or "left-wing authoritarianism" to value people's actual lives over other people's opinions. If it means one person that otherwise would have felt othered and unwanted now feels they can safely participate, then my effort wasn't in vain.

elements.text: Thanks

If it means one person that otherwise would have felt othered and unwanted now feels they can safely participate, then my effort wasn't in vain.

text: saying that one side of the argument "value people's actual lives over other people's opinions" is both excessively melodramtic and misrepresenting what's actually going on.  What you *really* mean is that you value some people's opinions over other people's opinions.  Nobody has even come close to calling for violence or for anyone to be banned, or anything extreme like that, it's just opinion on all sides.  Saying that one side of the argument is mere opinion and the other side is lives is extremely hypocritical.

I'm actually not nearly interested enough in this topic to spend all day reading articles about richard stallman, and I rather regret commenting on the subject in the first place

I mean, understanding the rise of transphobic rhetoric in the UK and the USA, and it's effect on the ability of non-cis people to seek medical care and function in society.
